item.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W6 Assignment 8
item.description:
Induction: the inference of a general law from particular instances.

Axiom/ principle: generally acknowledged truth.

to prove $âˆ€n$ A$(n)$

Method, principle of mathematical induction

  1. Prove A$(1)$
  2. Dominoes: $âˆ€n$ [ A$(n)$ â‡’ A$(n+1)$] induction step

Theorem: for any n, 1+2+3 â€¦â€¦ + n = 1/2n(n+1)

if n = 1, both side equal to 1, then the identity is true.

Assume A$(n)$ and deduce A$(n+1)$, the identity holds for all n

1+2+3 â€¦â€¦ + n+1 = 1/2(n+1)[(n+1)+1]

item.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W8 Quiz
item.description:
least upper bound

A set A of reals can have at most one least upper bound.

if a is LUB, then aâ‰¤b

if b is LUB, then bâ‰¤a

if a, b are both two LUBs, then b=a,

such as {42} has the only element 42 as both an upper bound and a lower bound.

lower bound

if a set A of reals has a lower bound, it has infinitely many lower bounds.
